Award.AwardTitle: BRAIN EAGER: Spatially-Resolved In Vivo Optogenetic Stimulation and Imaging Platform

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Boppart, Stephen A.
Proposal: 1450829
Title: BRAIN EAGER: Spatially-Resolved In Vivo Optogenetic Stimulation and Imaging Platform

Significance
The successful outcome of this research project will have a broad impact in neuroscience in addition to optical science and engineering. The PI will use implanted imaging fiber bundles that will enable
in vivo imaging as well as spatially-controlled optical stimulation and optical feedback of
large-area neural circuits. Current fibers only indiscriminately illuminate large-areas. Optogenetics is expected to make a broad impact in neuroscience, as well as medical science and clinical medicine in the future. This proposed research offers the potential to have an even greater impact by controlling the light stimulus and enhancing specificity in the control of neural circuits. The results of this project will be shared widely amongst the scientific and engineering communities, and also across wide segments of society in outreach activities. The new imaging and visualization capabilities will inspire K-12 students to think about how technology can be used to see things one cannot normally see, and how we can invent new ways of seeing the world around us and discovering new knowledge. Outreach activities will include demos of these imaging fiber bundles and novel light sources to K-12 and community groups through
annual Engineering Open House events, as well as integration of these technological methods in Prof. Boppart?s undergraduate ECE/BioE 467 Biophotonics and ECE/BioE 380 Biomedical Imaging
courses.

Technical Description
Optogenetics is a rapidly developing field with an ever-expanding toolkit of molecular biology
techniques to enable light-activated switching and control of cells, most commonly neurons.
Equally significant advances have occurred in optical science and engineering. By understanding
and exploiting physics-based principles of how light interacts in photonic crystal fibers (PCFs) and within imaging fiber bundles, it is possible to generate, control, and optimize a wide range of new optical parameters for in vivo optogenetic stimulation. Traditionally in in vivo optogenetic applications, light has been sent down single multi-mode optical fibers to diffusely illuminate the brain, relying on the molecular biology of optogenetically-modified neurons for cell and circuit specificity. This EAGER project will uniquely develop and demonstrate the use of imaging fiber bundles, and the generation of specific light pulse parameters to enable spatially-resolved optogenetic stimulation and imaging of neural circuits in vivo. These novel neurotechnologies will enable new investigations underlying behavior and cognition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Optogenetics is a rapidly developing field with an ever-expanding toolkit of molecular biology techniques to enable light-activated switching and control of cells, most commonly neurons. Equally significant advances have occurred in optical science and engineering. By understanding and exploiting physics-based principles of how light interacts in photonic crystal fibers (PCFs) and within imaging fiber bundles, it is possible to generate, control, and optimize a wide range of new optical parameters for in vivo optogenetic stimulation.

Traditionally in in vivo optogenetic applications, light has been sent down single multi-mode optical fibers to diffusely illuminate the brain, relying on the molecular biology of optogenetically-modified neurons for cell and circuit specificity. This EAGER project has uniquely developed and demonstrated the use of imaging fiber bundles, and the generation of specific light pulse parameters, to enable spatially-resolved optogenetic stimulation and imaging of neural circuits. These novel neurotechnologies will enable new investigations underlying behavior and cognition in animal models, and the functional parameters associated with communication in neural circuits.

Intellectual Merit

The intellectual merit of this proposed project was grounded in the ability to utilize imaging fiber bundles consisting of thousands of individually-addressable fibers, all within an outer diameter no larger than currently used multi-mode fibers. In conjunction, this project research generated new forms of ultrashort pulsed light to stimulate, modulate, and control the output of optogenetically-modified neurons. By providing spatially-resolved stimulation and imaging, and a new automated correlation algorithm, we have begun to elucidate new functional and emergent properties of neural circuits.

Broader Impact

The successful outcomes of this research project have a broad impact in not only neuroscience and psychology, but also in optical science and engineering. We have demonstrated these advances in vivo using implanted imaging fiber bundles that will enable in vivo imaging as well as spatially-controlled optical stimulation and optical feedback of large-area neural circuits, in contrast to current fibers that only broadly and indiscriminately illuminate large-areas. Just as optogenetics is expected to make a broad impact in neuroscience, as well as medical science and clinical medicine in the future, these research results offer the potential to have an even greater impact by controlling the light stimulus and enhancing specificity in the control of neural circuits.

Outcomes

There were three main outcomes from this research. First, a fully-functional optical platform was constructed and demonstrated with an imaging fiber bundle for in vivo spatially-resolved optical imaging and stimulation of neurons in a pre-clinical model. Second, an optical imaging and stimulation microscope was constructed for generating tailored shaped-pulse (coherent control) stimulation of optogenetic neurons, and this was used to show that by temporally and spectrally shaping the optical pulses, different outputs from neurons can be produced and controlled. Third, a neural circuit analysis algorithm was written and demonstrated, using optical images of neural activity as input, and analyzing the correlations of activity between neurons to determine their connections and communication in sparse neural circuits. The long-term goal of this research is to develop methods to optically interrogate, program, and control neural circuits in the living brain.

The results of this project were not only shared widely with the scientific and engineering communities, but also across wide segments of our society in outreach activities. The new imaging and visualization capabilities have inspired K-12 students to think about how technology can be used to see things we cannot normally see, and how we can invent new ways of seeing the world around us to discover new knowledge. Outreach activities included demonstrations of these imaging fiber bundles and novel light sources to K-12 and community groups through our annual Engineering Open House events, as well as integration of these technological methods into undergraduate (ECE/BioE 380 Biomedical Imaging) and graduate (ECE/BioE 467 Biophotonics) courses. During this project, two graduate students and one undergraduate student from under-represented groups (two Hispanic males, one Hispanic female) participated in this research.
